title: Microplastic Bioaccumulation Cascade
context: Plastic was marketed as recyclable. In reality, less than 9% of plastic ever produced has been recycled. The rest breaks down into microplastics — particles smaller than 5mm — that are now found everywhere: in ocean water, drinking water, food, air, human blood, placentas, and brain tissue. We are only beginning to understand the health effects of chronic microplastic exposure, but early research suggests endocrine disruption, inflammation, and potential carcinogenic effects. The plastic age created a contamination problem that will outlast every person alive today.
hypothesis: Plastic is recyclable and its environmental impact is manageable.

chain.root: Produce and dispose of plastic at industrial scale for 70+ years

effects.label: Microplastics contaminate every environment on Earth
effects.impact: Found in deepest ocean trenches, highest mountains, and Arctic ice

children.label: Plastic breaks down but never disappears — fragments into smaller particles
Microplastics in drinking water: average person ingests 5g of plastic per week
Airborne microplastics inhaled with every breath

effects.label: Bioaccumulation through the food chain
effects.impact: Microplastics found in 90%+ of seafood samples tested

children.label: Plankton ingest microplastics → fish eat plankton → humans eat fish
Agricultural soil contaminated by plastic mulch and sewage sludge
Microplastics found in fruits, vegetables, meat, and dairy

effects.label: Human health effects emerging from research
effects.impact: Microplastics found in human blood, lungs, placentas, and brain tissue

children.label: Endocrine disruption from plastic additives (BPA, phthalates)
Inflammatory response to plastic particles in tissues
Potential links to cardiovascular disease, reproductive issues, and cancer

effects.label: No viable cleanup or reversal technology exists
effects.impact: Contamination is effectively permanent on human timescales

children.label: Ocean cleanup addresses <1% of marine microplastics
Particles too small to filter from water and air at scale

dontIf: You're relying on recycling to solve the plastic problem — it doesn't work at scale
You're assuming microplastic exposure is safe because regulations haven't caught up
ifYouMust: Reduce plastic use at the source — the only effective strategy
Avoid heating food in plastic containers — heat accelerates microplastic release
Use water filters that capture microplastics (reverse osmosis, activated carbon)

alternatives.name: Material substitution
alternatives.note: Glass, metal, paper, and biodegradable materials for packaging — proven alternatives exist

alternatives.name: Extended producer responsibility
alternatives.note: Make producers responsible for end-of-life disposal — changes incentives at the source

alternatives.name: Plastic production caps
alternatives.note: Limit new plastic production rather than trying to manage waste after the fact

Long-term microplastic exposure in humans shows no measurable health effects in epidemiological studies

seo.description: Only 9% of plastic is recycled. Microplastics are in human blood, lungs, and brains. We ingest ~5g of plastic weekly. No cleanup technology exists at scale. The contamination is permanent.
